I appreciate your argument and the integral points you've brought forward regarding compensating employees for the restriction period and safeguarding the company's interests. And while I still uphold my earlier stance and agree in part, I maintain that this issue is not entirely black or white.

Your points emphasize the ideal functioning of noncompete deals; however, their real-world execution and the prevailing legal landscape can often disadvantage employees. While one may view noncompete deals as balanced and beneficial, the "fairness" is often determined by exceedingly complex legal language which might be done to the detriment of the employee. Also, compensation provided during the restriction period may not be sufficient to offset potential missed opportunities.

Moreover, if a company's proprietary information and trade secrets are indeed highly valuable, other protection mechanisms such as confidentiality agreements and patents can also serve to protect these without limiting an employee's career trajectory post-departure.

So while I can see the potential benefits of noncompete deals when crafted with equity and good regulation, I maintain that they should not be a "blanket approach" used by all businesses for all employees due to a potential imbalance that can affect the employment ecosystem. A calibrated approach based on the role's sensitivity and the employee's level within the organization might be more apt.
